questions.text: A 32-year-old man and his 29-year-old wife come to the physician because they have been unable to conceive despite regular unprotected sexual intercourse for 13 months. The woman reports regular menstrual cycles since the age of 13. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5–7 days. She has previously used a copper intrauterine device for contraception but had it removed 18 months ago. Ovulation predictor kits consistently turn positive around day 14. Neither of the couple has a history of serious illness or takes medications. They each smoked one pack of cigarettes daily until 1 year ago. The man works in construction and his wife is a secretary for a law firm. Examination of the scrotum in a standing position shows soft bands palpated in the upper pole of the left scrotum with an intact left testicle. Following Valsalva maneuver, the patient reports a dull, aching pain in his left hemiscrotum. A light held behind the scrotum does not shine through. The right scrotum appears normal. Semen studies show normal sperm count with moderately decreased motility and abnormal morphology. Which of the following is most likely to improve the patient's ability to conceive?

choices.text: Ligation of dilated pampiniform venous plexus
Surgical excision of the hydrocele sac

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In varicoceles, blood stasis within the scrotum increases the local temperature (which is usually 2°C below the average body temperature), potentially impairing sperm production. This patient would like to have children and has abnormal semen parameters (decreased motility and abnormal morphology). Surgical treatment of varicocele (e.g., microsurgical subinguinal varicocelectomy, percutaneous embolization) is required in complicated cases (e.g., infertility, pain), while conservative treatment may be considered in older patients. Varicocele treatment has been demonstrated to improve semen quality parameters, which may promote fertility.

Although varicocele is most common on the left side, ultrasound examination of the right side should also be conducted to rule out bilateral manifestation. Following varicocele treatment, this patient's semen quality should be analyzed every three months for at least one year or until conception.
Image Description:

A varicocele is a dilatation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum.

B) INCORRECT:

Orchidopexy is the standard surgical treatment for patients with cryptorchidism in prepubertal boys. Bilateral cryptorchidism is associated with an increased risk of oligospermia and infertility. However, this patient has no history of cryptorchidism, and, on physical examination, both testicles are within the scrotum. If this 32-year-old patient had newly discovered cryptorchidism, orchiectomy (rather than orchidopexy) would be the appropriate treatment because the remaining testicular tissue would no longer function but come with an elevated risk of testicular malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has a varicocele, which may negatively affect sperm quality, possibly leading to infertility. Conservative management with scrotal support and appropriate analgesics (e.g., NSAIDs) may be considered for older patients with varicoceles who have no desire to have more children and have only mild scrotal discomfort. In this patient, who is trying to conceive, symptomatic management will not improve his ability to conceive.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's occupation as a construction worker, which is likely associated with extensive physical activity including straining of the abdomen, puts him at an increased risk of developing an abdominal hernia. Smoking further increases this risk, as it weakens the connective tissue. Inguinal hernias that extend into the scrotum may appear as scrotal enlargement and an increase in size during the Valsalva maneuver is characteristic of any type of hernia. However, an inguinal hernia is associated with visible and palpable bulging of the groin and appears as a protruding mass on palpation. This patient's scrotal swelling is described as soft, palpable strands located on the upper pole of the testicles, which instead suggests varicocele.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision of the hydrocele sac is the appropriate treatment for symptomatic patients with a hydrocele. While a hydrocele may also manifest as a palpable unilateral scrotal swelling, the transillumination test would be positive. Soft bands on palpation and a negative transillumination make varicocele more likely. Furthermore, unlike varicoceles, hydroceles are not associated with infertility.

F) INCORRECT:

In young, sexually active patients with acute epididymitis, intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline are given to treat a potentially underlying Chlamydia trachomatis and/or N. gonorrhea infection. Although epididymitis may also cause unilateral scrotal swelling, patients usually present with fever, signs of lower urinary tract infection (e.g., dysuria, frequency, urethral discharge), or erythema of the overlying scrotal skin, none of which are present in this patient. Palpable scrotal bands are not a feature of epididymitis.
questions.hint: Physical examination findings of soft bands in the upper pole of the left scrotum (referred to as a “bag of worms” appearance), the onset of pain upon Valsalva maneuver, and a negative transillumination test are characteristic findings of scrotal varicocele.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has been healthy since. He is at the 60th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows normal scrotal rugae and a circumcised penis. There is a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. The scrotum is nontender and not enlarged. There is a palpable mass in the left inguinal canal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin therapy involves the administration of either human chorionic gonadotropin or gonadotropin-releasing hormone to stimulate gonadal steroidogenesis and promote testicular descent. However, the success rates of gonadotropin therapy are highly variable and there is a possibility of long-term adverse effects (e.g., low testicular volume, infertility) in infants who received gonadotropin therapy. Hormonal therapy with gonadotropins is not recommended for the treatment of cryptorchidism.

B) CORRECT:

Immediate surgical treatment of undescended testes is recommended starting from the corrected age of 6 months because spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after this time. Early surgery promotes normal testicular growth and improves the chances of fertility. Because the infant has a palpable testis in the inguinal canal, orchiopexy is the surgical procedure of choice. Orchiopexy should ideally be performed between 6–12 months, but no later than 24 months of corrected age.

The rate of cryptorchidism is higher in preterm infants, such as this patient, and in patients who are small for gestational age or have low birth weight. Complications of cryptorchidism include subfertility and testicular cancer (even in patients who underwent timely intervention), inguinal hernia (due to concurrent patent processus vaginalis), and testicular torsion.
Image Description:

Failure of one or both testicles to descend to their natural position in the scrotum. Most common variations (from top to bottom):

– abdominal testis (blue): the testicle is located proximal to the internal inguinal ring
– inguinal testis (green): the testicle is located inside the inguinal canal between the external and internal inguinal ring, preventing adequate mobilization (90% of cases)
– suprascrotal testis (purple): the testicle is located distal to the internal inguinal ring and above the scrotum

C) INCORRECT:

Orchiectomy for cryptorchidism may be indicated if the undescended testicle is hypoplastic, atrophic, or nonviable. Orchiectomy may also be indicated for an abdominal testis (especially in post-pubertal boys) to minimize the risk of testicular cancer or if the testicular vessels and vas deferens are too short to perform a scrotal orchiopexy, provided that the child has a normal contralateral testis. This patient has an inguinal cryptorchid testis and there is no reason to suspect impaired viability of the testis.

D) INCORRECT:

Exploration under anesthesia is recommended in infants with cryptorchidism and nonpalpable testes in order to evaluate for the presence and location of the testes. A nonpalpable testis may be absent (blind-ending cord structures indicate absent testes), atrophic, or located anywhere along the line of testicular descent (intra-abdominal or within the inguinal canal). Since the left testicle of this infant is palpable in the left inguinal canal, exploration under anesthesia is not necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum testosterone level is indicated in addition to gonadotropin and Müllerian inhibiting substance assay to evaluate male infants with bilaterally nonpalpable testes. Testosterone is usually normal in unilateral cryptorchidism and significantly decreased in bilateral cryptorchidism. Assessment of testosterone is not indicated in this boy with unilateral cryptorchidism.

F) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis can be considered in the evaluation of a phenotypically male infant with bilateral nonpalpable testes to evaluate for the presence of a uterus (e.g., due to congenital adrenal hyperplasia). However, an ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis in a patient with a palpable undescended testis is unlikely to contribute to the diagnosis or affect the course of treatment. Therefore, it is not indicated in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous descent of a cryptorchid testis rarely occurs after 6 months of age. Re-evaluating this patient at 3 years of age would increase the risk of complications (e.g., infertility, testicular torsion). Therefore, another step in management is required.

H) INCORRECT:

Genetic karyotyping is indicated in male infants with bilaterally nonpalpable testes to identify if the condition is due to true bilateral cryptorchidism or a disorder of sexual development (e.g., Klinefelter syndrome). It is not indicated in this patient with unilateral cryptorchidism.

I) INCORRECT:

Reassurance for cryptorchidism is indicated in boys < 4 months of age since the majority of testicles descend spontaneously by 4 months of age. Spontaneous descent most likely occurs at this time because of a gonadotropic hormone surge (FSH and LH) at around 60–90 days of life. However, spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after 6 months of age and, therefore, reassurance is not appropriate because uncorrected cryptorchidism is associated with subfertility, infertility, testicular torsion, inguinal hernia, and testicular malignancy.
questions.hint: Spontaneous testicular descent should occur by 6 months of age.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a right-sided scrotal swelling for the past 2 months. The swelling is intermittent and appears usually after the patient has been taken outdoors in a baby carrier, and disappears the next morning. The patient was born at term without complications and has been healthy. Examination shows a 3-cm, soft, nontender, and fluctuant right scrotal mass that is reducible and does not extend into the inguinal area. A light held behind the scrotum shines through. There are no bowel sounds in the mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The scrotal swelling in this infant is typical of a congenital communicating hydrocele, which occurs due to a failed closure of the processus vaginalis during development. This condition resolves spontaneously in most cases by 1 year of age, as the patent processus vaginalis normally closes during the first year of life. Moreover, since this infant's hydrocele is small, it is unlikely to cause pressure-related complications, such as atrophy of the testis or skin erosions. Reassurance and follow-up is, therefore, the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

The preliminary diagnosis of a hydrocele can be confirmed by ultrasonography, which typically reveals anechoic fluid. Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis is the procedure of choice for pediatric communicating hydroceles which do not resolve spontaneously by 1 year of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous drainage is a treatment option for cases of hydrocele in adult patients for whom surgery is contraindicated and when remaining fertility is not a concern. However, drainage is not recommended for congenital hydroceles, since here the hydrocele communicates with the peritoneal cavity and contains peritoneal fluid. In these cases, aspiration brings no benefit, as the processus vaginalis will again fill with peritoneal fluid after the drainage, and hence the hydrocele will recur.

C) INCORRECT:

Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis is the procedure of choice for pediatric communicating hydroceles that do not resolve spontaneously. The processus vaginalis is ligated high within the internal inguinal ring to prevent peritoneal fluid from flowing into the tunica vaginalis and thereby reduce the hydrocele. However, considering the age of this child, ligation is not indicated at this stage.

D) INCORRECT:

Orchidopexy is the surgical procedure employed to permanently fix a testis in the scrotum for cases of either cryptorchidism or testicular torsion. Typically, an unaffected side is also prophylactically operated on. Testicular torsion is known to occur in neonates, and it could be either in-utero or postnatal. Prenatal torsion presents with few localized findings, but postnatal torsion could present with considerable scrotal swelling. However, the swelling would be extremely tender. In cryptorchidism, the scrotal sac would be empty, which is not the case in this child.

E) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic hernia repair is indicated for uncomplicated hernias (without signs of bowel obstruction or strangulation), usually carried out as an elective procedure. Inguinal hernias that extend into the scrotum may appear as a scrotal enlargement that fluctuates in size. However, they do not transilluminate.

F) INCORRECT:

Excision of dilated pampiniform plexus or varicocelectomy is the primary form of treatment for varicoceles. This child presents with a fluctuant, soft scrotal swelling, which could possibly be a varicocele. However, a varicocele would be typically felt like a “bag of worms” on palpation and would not transilluminate. Moreover, varicoceles are more likely to occur in males 15–25 years of age rather than in infants and are not seen as reducible swellings.
Image Description:

Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.
questions.hint: This infant presents with an asymptomatic right-sided scrotal swelling that is fluctuant, transilluminates and does not extend into the inguinal region. The swelling increases after the baby has been carried and decreases after sleep. These features are characteristic of a congenital communicating hydrocele.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of painless enlargement of his left scrotum for the past 2 weeks. The patient reports that the enlargement is worse in the evenings, especially after playing soccer. He has not had any trauma to the testes. He has not had inguinal pain. He started to become sexually active with his girlfriend 3 weeks ago; they use condoms regularly. There is no personal or family history of serious illness and he takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the external genitalia shows no groin protrusion and no penile discharge or lesions. Inguinal lymph nodes are normal. There is a palpable soft, irregular swelling above the left testis. This swelling is more prominent while standing and disappears in the supine position. Right scrotal examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The risk of bowel strangulation is increased in patients with inguinal and scrotal hernias, which can manifest as a painless scrotal swelling that increases in size on standing up and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. However, such hernias typically manifest with pain localized to the inguinal region and a visible or palpable groin bulge. An isolated soft scrotal mass is not characteristic of a groin hernia.

B) INCORRECT:

A scrotal hematoma can occur following the rupture of a varicocele, but this complication is extremely rare and only a few cases have been reported to date.

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for testicular torsion include puberty (due to the sudden increase in testicular volume), testicular tumors, testicles with a horizontal lie, undescended testes, a spermatic cord with a long intrascrotal portion, and extension of the tunica vaginalis over the proximal spermatic cord (bell-clapper anatomical variant). However, this patient has a varicocele, which does not increase the risk of testicular torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism, which manifests as an empty scrotal sac, is a known risk factor for a testicular tumor. A palpable lump may be present in the inguinal region if the undescended testis is located within the inguinal canal. In this patient, however, both the testes are palpated within the scrotal sac. Intermittent hemiscrotal swelling with cord-like structures above the testis indicates a varicocele, which is not a known risk factor for testicular tumors.

E) CORRECT:

Varicoceles can result in testicular atrophy and infertility. The most probable mechanism is impaired spermatogenesis as a result of increased testicular temperature and testicular ischemia (due to increased intratesticular pressure, venous stasis, and/or vasoconstriction secondary to catecholamine reflux from the adrenal gland). The diagnosis of a varicocele is confirmed by ultrasonography, which should reveal dilated pampiniform veins.

In young men, semen analysis should be performed regularly to assess sperm number and quality. Most asymptomatic patients do not require intervention. Definitive treatment with laparoscopic varicocelectomy or percutaneous embolization is indicated for those with intractable discomfort and/or abnormalities on semen analysis.
Image Description:

A varicocele is a dilatation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum.
questions.hint: Vague discomfort and soft, irregular swelling in the scrotal region that enlarges on standing or with a Valsalva maneuver suggests a varicocele, which most commonly occurs during adolescence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The patient reports that he first noticed the swelling several weeks ago, but it is not always present. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. His father was diagnosed with a seminoma at the age of 25 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?

choices.text: Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis
Herniation of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A patent processus vaginalis results in a communicating hydrocele and manifests with a fluctuant, painless scrotal mass that transilluminates. However, a communicating hydrocele will increase in size on coughing/straining due to its communication with the peritoneal cavity. Also, a communicating hydrocele is seen in infants and young children whereas this patient is in his 5th decade of life, making this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the pampiniform plexus of veins results in a varicocele, which, if symptomatic, manifests as a dragging sensation/dull pain in the affected scrotum. However, varicoceles typically manifest at a younger age (puberty/adolescence) and the dilated veins result in a characteristic "bag of worms” feeling on palpation. Furthermore, the transillumination test is negative in varicocele and varicoceles usually affect the left side.

C) INCORRECT:

Twisting of the spermatic cord causes testicular torsion. Testicular torsion can cause reactive fluid collection around the testis (reactive secondary hydrocele), which may be visible as a transilluminated scrotal swelling, which is seen here. However, patients with this condition present acutely with sudden, severe testicular pain, often associated with nausea and vomiting, and the affected testis would be tender on palpation. Furthermore, testicular torsion usually occurs in neonates and adolescents.

D) CORRECT:

Since this patient has no signs of ongoing inflammation, no history of recent testicular trauma, and a normal testis on palpation, he most likely has a primary (idiopathic) hydrocele, which is caused by an imbalance in the rate of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis. Primary hydroceles differ from secondary hydroceles in that the underlying cause of fluid accumulation within the tunica vaginalis is not known (idiopathic). Secondary hydroceles can either be communicating or noncommunicating and are often found in newborns, although they typically resolve spontaneously. In reactive hydroceles, inflammation (e.g., epididymitis, orchitis), trauma, or neoplasia causes an imbalance in fluid secretion and absorption by the tunica vaginalis.

E) INCORRECT:

An inguinal hernia can also manifest as a nontender scrotal mass that may vary in size and if the content is omentum, absent bowel sounds within the mass. However, since an inguinal hernia enters the scrotum through the superficial inguinal ring, the examiner will not be able to palpate normal tissue above the mass. Since the contents of an inguinal hernia are solid, the transillumination test will be negative. The contents of an inguinal hernia are in direct communication with the peritoneal cavity, meaning that coughing/straining will increase the size of the mass (unless it is an obstructed/strangulated hernia).

F) INCORRECT:

Impaired lymphatic drainage causing scrotal swelling (usually bilateral) can occur in patients who have undergone iliac lymphadenectomy, pelvic irradiation, or those who have lymphatic filariasis due to Wuchereria bancrofti infection. This patient has no history of undergoing these procedures and filariasis has been eradicated within the United States. Moreover, the transillumination test is often negative in acquired hydroceles due to lymphatic obstruction because the scrotum is thickened and the hydrocele fluid is often turbid and chylous.

G) INCORRECT:

Although testicular cancer can manifest as a painless scrotal swelling and is associated with a positive family history, palpation would generally reveal a testicular mass and the transillumination test would be negative (unless there is a reactive fluid collection around the testis). Some testicular tumors may not be palpable and the testes may appear normal on examination. However, it is unlikely that a nonpalpable testicular tumor would cause a reactive hydrocele.
questions.hint: This patient's fluctuant, painless scrotal mass that does not reduce in a supine position and positive transillumination of the scrotum is highly characteristic of a hydrocele.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The swelling started several weeks ago but is not always present. Physical examination shows an 8-cm, soft, cystic nontender right-sided scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?

choices.text: Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by tunica vaginalis
Failure of processus vaginalis to obliterate
Extension of abdominal contents through the inguinal canal
Dilation and tortuosity of veins in the pampiniform plexus
Primary germ cell neoplasia of the testicle
Obstruction in lymphatic drainage of the scrotum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Since this patient has no signs of ongoing inflammation, no history of recent testicular trauma, and a normal testis on palpation, he most likely has a primary/idiopathic hydrocele, which is caused by an imbalance in the rate of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis. Primary hydroceles differ from secondary/reactive hydroceles in that the underlying cause of fluid accumulation within the tunica vaginalis is not known (idiopathic). In secondary/reactive hydroceles, inflammation (e.g., epididymitis, orchitis), trauma, or neoplasia causes an imbalance in fluid secretion and absorption by the tunica vaginalis.

B) INCORRECT:

Failure of the processus vaginalis to obliterate results in a communicating hydrocele and is seen in infants and young children. Although a child with a communicating hydrocele will have the same clinical findings as this patient, the onset of this patient's symptoms in the 6th decade of life makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, in contrast to this case, a communicating hydrocele would increase in size on coughing/straining due to its communication with the peritoneal cavity.

A patent processus vaginalis is also the cause of indirect inguinal hernia, which can be congenital or acquired and also present as a nontender scrotal mass that may vary in size and, if the content is omentum, absent bowel sounds within the mass. However, since an inguinal hernia enters the scrotum through the superficial inguinal ring with solid content, the examiner will not be able to palpate normal tissue above the mass and the transillumination test will be negative. It would also increase in coughing/straining (unless it is an obstructed/strangulated hernia).

C) INCORRECT:

An inguinal hernia can also present as a nontender scrotal mass that may vary in size and, if the content is omentum, absent bowel sounds within the mass. However, since an inguinal hernia enters the scrotum through the superficial inguinal ring, the examiner will not be able to palpate normal tissue above the mass. Since the contents of an inguinal hernia are solid, the transillumination test will be negative. The contents of an inguinal hernia are in direct communication with the peritoneal cavity, meaning that coughing/straining will increase the size of the mass (unless it is an obstructed/strangulated hernia).

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation and tortuosity of the pampiniform plexus of veins cause a varicocele, which, if symptomatic, manifests as a dragging sensation/dull pain in the affected scrotum. However, varicoceles typically present at a younger age (puberty/adolescence) and the dilated veins will present as a characteristic "bag of worms” feeling on palpation. Furthermore, a transillumination test will be negative in varicocele. Lastly, varicoceles are usually left-sided.

E) INCORRECT:

Although testicular cancer can manifest as a painless scrotal swelling, palpation would generally reveal a testicular mass and the transillumination test would be negative (unless there is reactive fluid collection around the testis). Some testicular tumors may be nonpalpable and the testes may appear normal on examination. However, it is unlikely that a nonpalpable testicular tumor would cause a reactive hydrocele.

F) INCORRECT:

Obstruction in lymphatic drainage causing scrotal swelling (usually bilateral) causes hydrocele and can occur in patients who have undergone iliac lymphadenectomy, pelvic irradiation, or those who have lymphatic filariasis due to Wuchereria bancrofti infection. This patient has no history of undergoing these procedures and filariasis has been eradicated from the United States. Moreover, the transillumination test is often negative in hydroceles caused by lymphatic obstruction, since the scrotum is thickened and the hydrocele fluid is often turbid and chylous.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a fluctuant, painless scrotal mass that transilluminates and does not reduce in a supine position. These features are suggestive of hydrocele.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg (11-lbs) weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Venous blood drainage from the anterior scrotum occurs via the external pudendal veins into the great saphenous vein. However, the palpable strands (i.e., “bag of worms”) in the right hemiscrotum developed due to dilatation of the pampiniform plexus, which receives blood from the testes rather than the scrotum. Obstruction of the right external pudendal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Venous blood return from the prostate travels via the prostatic venous plexus to the internal iliac veins and can provide a route for the hematogenous spread of prostate cancer metastases or infections to the spine. The right testicular vein, however, does not drain into the right internal iliac vein, so obstruction would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

C) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectal veins, part of the systemic circulation, drain the rectum below the dentate line and connect with the portal system via anastomosis with the superior rectal veins. Due to this anastomosis, portal hypertension can lead to anorectal varices. Obstruction of the right inferior rectal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele because the right testicular vein does not drain into the right inferior rectal vein.

D) INCORRECT:

While the left testicular vein empties into the left renal vein, the right testicular vein does not empty into the right renal vein. Obstruction of the left renal vein (e.g., nutcracker syndrome, thrombosis) can result in a left-sided varicocele, but this patient's right-sided scrotal enlargement cannot be explained by right renal vein obstruction.

E) CORRECT:

Unilateral right-sided varicoceles arise due to obstruction of right pampiniform venous plexus drainage via the testicular vein into the inferior vena cava (IVC). Varicoceles are more commonly left-sided, because the left testicular vein drains into the relatively high-pressure left renal vein at a 90-degree angle, while the right testicular vein drains into the low-pressure IVC. Unilateral right-sided varicoceles should raise suspicion for a mass in the retroperitoneal space (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, lymphoma, Ormond disease) blocking the venous blood return. This patient's history of weight loss, fatigue, smoking history, and right flank tenderness is concerning for an underlying right-sided renal cell carcinoma obstructing the right testicular vein and causing the varicocele.
Image Description:

Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.
questions.hint: Presentation with right scrotal swelling and heaviness, exacerbated by Valsalva maneuver and alleviated by recumbency, in combination with palpable strands (i.e., “bag of worms”) and a negative transillumination test on examination suggests a right-sided varicocele.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with a progressively enlarging right-sided scrotal mass, which he first noticed several weeks ago and describes as nontender but slightly uncomfortable.
On physical examination, his vital signs are normal. Head, neck, cardiovascular, and respiratory examination findings are within normal limits, and an abdominal examination is unremarkable. Examination of the scrotum reveals a right-sided varicocele, with a classic “bag-of-worms” feel on palpation. It is equally present in both the standing and the supine position.
What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step in this case?

choices.text: Order an ultrasound of the scrotum
Advise the patient to wear loose-fitting underwear and return for follow-up in 2 to 3 months
Measure serum testosterone and luteinizing-hormone levels
Measure alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels
Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a scrotal ultrasound may confirm the presence of a varicocele, it would not diagnose the underlying cause of a varicocele that does not shrink in the supine position.

B) INCORRECT:

Deferring further evaluation and having the patient wear loose-fitting underwear does not address the primary cause of his physical findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing for evidence of hypogonadism is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing for tumor markers of testicular cancer is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

A varicocele is an enlarged venous plexus in the scrotum. Varicoceles are fairly common on the left side because of the higher pressure within the left gonadal vein compared with the right gonadal vein. This difference is due to the differing drainage of the two veins — the left gonadal vein drains at a right angle into the left renal vein, whereas the right gonadal vein inserts into the inferior vena cava at a more acute angle, which makes drainage easier. Bilateral varicoceles occur in around 30% of patients, whereas an isolated right-sided varicocele is more unusual.

In general, a unilateral right-sided varicocele should always raise concern for the possibility of obstruction from a retroperitoneal mass. Although retrospective studies have not shown a significantly higher rate of malignancy in patients with right-sided varicoceles than in those with left-sided or bilateral varicoceles, these studies were small and were not conclusive; thus, imaging to rule out compression from a mass remains the standard of care for a right-sided varicocele.

Choosing the Best Next Step in This Case

In this particular case, the right-sided location of the varicocele is not the only unusual feature in the patient’s clinical presentation. The rapid onset is also unusual, as most varicoceles worsen slowly over months to years. Furthermore, the varicocele was equally present in both the standing and the supine position; most varicoceles will diminish in size in the supine position compared with the standing position unless they are quite advanced (grade 3 varicoceles may not diminish in size).

The constellation of these unusual features in the absence of genital trauma should raise suspicion for obstruction from a retroperitoneal mass or an intra-abdominal tumor (usually renal cancer). Therefore, the most appropriate next diagnostic step in this case is to perform CT of the abdomen and pelvis to assess for the presence of an intra-abdominal tumor.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic step for a man who presents with a new nondiminishing, right-sided varicocele is CT of the abdomen and pelvis.

questions.text:
A male infant is evaluated in the office on his fourth day of life. After an uncomplicated pregnancy, he was born at 36 weeks’ gestation weighing 2350 grams. He was monitored in the special care nursery for 24 hours after which he was transferred to a room with his mother and discharged home on his second day of life. He is breastfeeding well and is voiding and passing meconium normally. His weight is down 5% from his birth weight.
You are unable to palpate the left testicle in the scrotum or at the inguinal ring. The right testicle is palpable, and both the right testicle and the penis appear normal. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Expectant management for several months, followed by orchiopexy by one year of age if the cryptorchidism is not resolved
Referral for orchiopexy within the next month
Expectant management through early childhood, followed by orchiopexy if the cryptorchidism is not resolved by age 3 years
Expectant management through puberty, followed by orchiopexy if the cryptorchidism is not resolved within one year after sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 3 is reached

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of imaging to locate a nonpalpable testicle has been controversial. Although ultrasonography is noninvasive, safe, and readily available, it is not indicated in the first few months of life given that many children experience spontaneous descent.

B) CORRECT:

Cryptorchidism, or undescended testes, affects up to 5% of male full-term infants and an even larger percentage of preterm infants. Low birth weight for gestational age is also an independent risk factor.

Recommendations have gradually lowered the ideal age for surgical correction of cryptorchidism; the current consensus is 6 to 12 months of age.

For many infants, the testicle descends during the first few months of life, so initial expectant management is reasonable. However, if the testicle is not in the scrotal sac by age 6 months corrected for gestational age, the infant should be referred for surgical repair, which is typically performed before one year of age.

Despite clear consensus about the importance of early surgical correction of cryptorchidism, not all infants are appropriately referred. All cases of cryptorchidism that do not spontaneously resolve in the first 6 to 12 months of life require treatment.

Key learning point: Cryptorchidism should be corrected with orchiopexy no later than age 12 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Recommendations have gradually lowered the ideal age for surgical correction of cryptorchidism; the current consensus is 6 to 12 months of age.

For many infants, the testicle descends during the first few months of life, so initial expectant management is reasonable. However, if the testicle is not in the scrotal sac by age 6 months corrected for gestational age, the infant should be referred for surgical repair, which is typically performed before one year of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Recommendations have gradually lowered the ideal age for surgical correction of cryptorchidism; the current consensus is 6 to 12 months of age.

Recent studies comparing testicular biopsies from surgical corrections performed at 9 months versus 3 years of age have further supported recommendations for orchiopexy prior to one year of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism is known to increase the risk for testicular cancer and is associated with future infertility. The cancer risk drops significantly when surgical correction occurs before puberty but remains higher than in the normal population. Recommendations have gradually lowered the ideal age for surgical correction of cryptorchidism; the current consensus is 6 to 12 months of age.

Retrospectively, it has been shown that men who underwent surgical repair of cryptorchidism after puberty have a significantly higher risk for testicular cancer than those who underwent surgical repair before puberty.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks’ gestation without complications and has been healthy since birth. His growth and development have been normal.
His vital signs, chest examination, and cardiovascular examination are normal. There is no abdominal tenderness. Genitourinary examination reveals that the patient is uncircumcised. There is a nontender mass in the left inguinal canal that cannot be moved with palpation or other maneuvers, and the testicle is not palpable in the left scrotum. The right hemiscrotum is normal. There are no rashes or skin lesions.
Which one of the following additional findings is most likely to be evident on this patient's physical examination?

choices.text: Palpation of what feels like a bag of worms in the scrotum
A scrotal fluid collection that transilluminates
Edema and erythema of the skin overlying the inguinal canal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Palpation of what feels like a bag of worms in the scrotum is suggestive of a varicocele. A varicocele is a collection of enlarged veins in the pampiniform plexus, the venous network that drains the testes and surrounds the spermatic cord. Given that this patient has no palpable testicle in the left hemiscrotum, a varicocele should not be found there.

B) INCORRECT:

A scrotal fluid collection that transilluminates is characteristic of a hydrocele, not an undescended testicle.

C) CORRECT:

The finding of fullness in the inguinal canal without a palpable mass in the scrotum is consistent with an undescended testicle (cryptorchidism). Retractile testes may initially be found in the inguinal canal but can typically be moved down (or “milked”) into the scrotum. A true undescended testicle cannot be milked but will typically descend spontaneously. If it does not do so by 6 months of age, referral to a pediatric urologist or surgeon is recommended.

Cryptorchidism may be an isolated finding, as in this patient, or may be associated with other congenital abnormalities. It is more common in preterm infants than full-term infants.

A poorly rugated scrotum or hemiscrotum is a common finding associated with undescended testicles.

Key learning point: Fullness in the inguinal canal, lack of a palpable scrotal mass, and a poorly rugated scrotum are features consistent with cryptorchidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema and edema of the skin overlying the inguinal canal may be seen with an incarcerated hernia. An inguinal hernia typically manifests as a reducible inguinal mass, and often the parent reports that the child has a history of swelling that comes and goes. The hernia may not be evident during physical examination, but if it is, it would be associated with a reducible mass, not an immovable one as seen in this patient. Furthermore, an incarcerated hernia is typically associated with pain and tenderness and is not likely to be detected incidentally during a routine well-child visit.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatosplenomegaly may be associated with inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, this patient has features (a mass in the inguinal canal that cannot be moved and an absent testicle in the scrotum) that are more consistent with an undescended testicle than with inguinal lymphadenopathy. In addition, he has no evidence of systemic illness.

questions.text:
A one-day-old male infant, who was born at 35 weeks’ gestation after limited prenatal care, is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress requiring mechanical ventilation, with concern for pulmonary hypoplasia. His examination is notable for a wrinkled appearance of the abdominal wall. A renal ultrasound reveals bladder distention and hydronephrosis, as well as severely dysplastic kidneys bilaterally.
Which one of the following additional physical examination findings would suggest a diagnosis of Eagle-Barrett syndrome in this patient?

choices.text: Heart murmur consistent with a ventricular septal defect

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

About 75% of affected patients also have non-urinary-tract abnormalities, most often cardiac, pulmonary, and orthopedic. Ventricular septal defects and hip dysplasia may occur in patients with prune-belly syndrome but are not part of the diagnostic triad.

B) CORRECT:

Prune-belly syndrome (also called Eagle-Barret syndrome) has the characteristic features of abdominal-wall flaccidity, urologic abnormalities, and bilateral cryptorchidism. Boys are affected ten times more frequently than girls. (Historically, some providers believed that only boys were affected, but there is likely a spectrum of disease that can manifest in girls as well.) The exact cause is unknown, but several hypotheses exist, including mesodermal arrest and downstream effects of bladder obstruction. Ureters are typically dilated and tortuous, and renal dysplasia is present in roughly half of all cases. Seventy-five percent of children with prune-belly syndrome have vesicoureteral reflux.

About 75% of affected patients also have non-urinary-tract abnormalities, most often cardiac, pulmonary, and orthopedic. Prognosis depends on the degree of renal dysfunction and pulmonary hypoplasia. Historically, half of patients with prune-belly syndrome died in infancy, often as a result of pulmonary hypoplasia. More recent studies document a survival rate of up to 90%, but a third of survivors require dialysis or renal transplantation.

Key learning point: The characteristic clinical triad of prune-belly (Eagle-Barrett) syndrome consists of an anomalous urinary tract, deficiency of the abdominal musculature, and bilateral intra-abdominal (undescended) testes.

C) INCORRECT:

Microcephaly and choanal atresia are not known to be associated with prune-belly syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Microcephaly and choanal atresia are not known to be associated with prune-belly syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

About 75% of affected patients also have non-urinary-tract abnormalities, most often cardiac, pulmonary, and orthopedic. Ventricular septal defects and hip dysplasia may occur in patients with prune-belly syndrome but are not part of the diagnostic triad.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the office because of a right-sided scrotal swelling for the past 2 months. The swelling is intermittent and appears usually after the patient has been taken outdoors in a baby carrier, and disappears the next morning. The patient was born at term without complications and has been healthy. Examination shows a 3-cm, soft, nontender, and fluctuant right scrotal mass that is reducible and does not extend into the inguinal area. A light held behind the scrotum shines through. There are no bowel sounds in the mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The scrotal swelling in this infant is typical of a congenital communicating hydrocele, which occurs due to a failed closure of the processus vaginalis during development. This condition resolves spontaneously in most cases by 1 year of age, as the patent processus vaginalis normally closes during the first year of life. Moreover, since this infant's hydrocele is small, it is unlikely to cause pressure-related complications, such as atrophy of the testis or skin erosions. Reassurance and follow-up is, therefore, the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

The preliminary diagnosis of a hydrocele can be confirmed by ultrasonography, which typically reveals anechoic fluid. Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis is the procedure of choice for pediatric communicating hydroceles which do not resolve spontaneously by 1 year of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous drainage is a treatment option for cases of hydrocele in adult patients for whom surgery is contraindicated and when remaining fertility is not a concern. However, drainage is not recommended for congenital hydroceles, since here the hydrocele communicates with the peritoneal cavity and contains peritoneal fluid. In these cases, aspiration brings no benefit, as the processus vaginalis will again fill with peritoneal fluid after the drainage, and hence the hydrocele will recur.

C) INCORRECT:

Orchidopexy is the surgical procedure employed to permanently fix a testis in the scrotum for cases of either cryptorchidism or testicular torsion. Typically, an unaffected side is also prophylactically operated on. Testicular torsion is known to occur in neonates, and it could be either in-utero or postnatal. Prenatal torsion presents with few localized findings, but postnatal torsion could present with considerable scrotal swelling. However, the swelling would be extremely tender. In cryptorchidism, the scrotal sac would be empty, which is not the case in this child.

D) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic hernia repair is indicated for uncomplicated hernias (without signs of bowel obstruction or strangulation), usually carried out as an elective procedure. Inguinal hernias that extend into the scrotum may appear as a scrotal enlargement that fluctuates in size. However, they do not transilluminate.

E) INCORRECT:

Excision of dilated pampiniform plexus or varicocelectomy is the primary form of treatment for varicoceles. This child presents with a fluctuant, soft scrotal swelling, which could possibly be a varicocele. However, a varicocele would be typically felt like a “bag of worms” on palpation and would not transilluminate. Moreover, varicoceles are more likely to occur in males 15–25 years of age rather than in infants and are not seen as reducible swellings
Image Description:

Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.
questions.hint: This infant presents with an asymptomatic right-sided scrotal swelling that is fluctuant, transilluminates and does not extend into the inguinal region. The swelling increases after the baby has been carried and decreases after sleep. These features are characteristic of a congenital communicating hydrocele.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the office for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has been healthy since. He is at the 60th percentile for length and weight. Examination shows normal scrotal rugae and a circumcised penis. There is a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. The scrotum is nontender and not enlarged. There is a palpable mass in the left inguinal canal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Immediate surgical treatment of undescended testes is recommended starting from the corrected age of 6 months because spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after this time. Early surgery promotes normal testicular growth and improves the chances of fertility. Because the infant has a palpable testis in the inguinal canal, orchiopexy is the surgical procedure of choice. Orchiopexy should ideally be performed between 6–12 months, but no later than 24 months of corrected age.

The rate of cryptorchidism is higher in preterm infants, such as this patient, and in patients who are small for gestational age or have low birth weight. Complications of cryptorchidism include subfertility and testicular cancer (even in patients who underwent timely intervention), inguinal hernia (due to concurrent patent processus vaginalis), and testicular torsion.
Image Description:

Failure of one or both testicles to descend to their natural position in the scrotum. Most common variations (from top to bottom):

– abdominal testis (blue): the testicle is located proximal to the internal inguinal ring
– inguinal testis (green): the testicle is located inside the inguinal canal between the external and internal inguinal ring, preventing adequate mobilization (90% of cases)
– suprascrotal testis (purple): the testicle is located distal to the internal inguinal ring and above the scrotum

B) INCORRECT:

Orchiectomy for cryptorchidism may be indicated if the undescended testicle is hypoplastic, atrophic, or nonviable. Orchiectomy may also be indicated for an abdominal testis (especially in post-pubertal boys) to minimize the risk of testicular cancer or if the testicular vessels and vas deferens are too short to perform a scrotal orchiopexy, provided that the child has a normal contralateral testis. This patient has an inguinal cryptorchid testis and there is no reason to suspect impaired viability of the testis.

C) INCORRECT:

Exploration under anesthesia is recommended in infants with cryptorchidism and nonpalpable testes in order to evaluate for the presence and location of the testes. A nonpalpable testis may be absent (blind-ending cord structures indicate absent testes), atrophic, or located anywhere along the line of testicular descent (intra-abdominal or within the inguinal canal). Since the left testicle of this infant is palpable in the left inguinal canal, exploration under anesthesia is not necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous descent of a cryptorchid testis rarely occurs after 6 months of age. Re-evaluating this patient at 3 years of age would increase the risk of complications (e.g., infertility, testicular torsion). Therefore, another step in management is required.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance for cryptorchidism is indicated in boys < 4 months of age since the majority of testicles descend spontaneously by 4 months of age. Spontaneous descent most likely occurs at this time because of a gonadotropic hormone surge (FSH and LH) at around 60–90 days of life. However, spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after 6 months of age and, therefore, reassurance is not appropriate because uncorrected cryptorchidism is associated with subfertility, infertility, testicular torsion, inguinal hernia, and testicular malignancy.
questions.hint: Spontaneous testicular descent should occur by 6 months of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a progressively enlarging right-sided scrotal mass, which he first noticed several weeks ago and describes as nontender but slightly uncomfortable. On physical examination, his vital signs are normal. Head, neck, cardiovascular, and respiratory examination findings are within normal limits, and an abdominal examination is unremarkable. Examination of the scrotum reveals a right-sided varicocele, with a classic “bag-of-worms” feel on palpation. It is equally present in both the standing and the supine position. What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step in this case?

choices.text: Order an ultrasound of the scrotum
Advise the patient to wear loose-fitting underwear and return for follow-up in 2 to 3 months
Measure serum testosterone and luteinizing-hormone levels
Measure alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels
Obtain CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a scrotal ultrasound may confirm the presence of a varicocele, it would not diagnose the underlying cause of a varicocele that does not shrink in the supine position.

B) INCORRECT:

Deferring further evaluation and having the patient wear loose-fitting underwear does not address the primary cause of his physical findings.

C) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing for evidence of hypogonadism is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Laboratory testing for tumor markers of testicular cancer is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

A varicocele is an enlarged venous plexus in the scrotum. Varicoceles are fairly common on the left side because of the higher pressure within the left gonadal vein compared with the right gonadal vein. This difference is due to the differing drainage of the two veins — the left gonadal vein drains at a right angle into the left renal vein, whereas the right gonadal vein inserts into the inferior vena cava at a more acute angle, which makes drainage easier. Bilateral varicoceles occur in around 30% of patients, whereas an isolated right-sided varicocele is more unusual. In general, a unilateral right-sided varicocele should always raise concern for the possibility of obstruction from a retroperitoneal mass. The constellation of these unusual features in the absence of genital trauma should raise suspicion for obstruction from a retroperitoneal mass or an intra-abdominal tumor (usually renal cancer). Therefore, the most appropriate next diagnostic step in this case is to perform CT of the abdomen and pelvis to assess for the presence of an intra-abdominal tumor.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic step for a man who presents with a new nondiminishing, right-sided varicocele is CT of the abdomen and pelvis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office because of swelling and unusual heaviness of his scrotum that he first noticed a few weeks ago. The symptoms improve when he is lying in bed. He also reports a 5-kg (11-lbs) weight loss and increasing fatigue over the past 6 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of his right flank. There are soft strands palpable in the right hemiscrotum superior of the right testis. The strands increase with Valsalva maneuver. Applying a bright light to the right hemiscrotum shows no transillumination. Obstruction of venous drainage into which of the following vessels is most likely responsible for this patient's scrotal enlargement?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Venous blood drainage from the anterior scrotum occurs via the external pudendal veins into the great saphenous vein. However, the palpable strands (i.e., “bag of worms”) in the right hemiscrotum developed due to dilatation of the pampiniform plexus, which receives blood from the testes rather than the scrotum. Obstruction of the right external pudendal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Venous blood return from the prostate travels via the prostatic venous plexus to the internal iliac veins and can provide a route for the hematogenous spread of prostate cancer metastases or infections to the spine. The right testicular vein, however, does not drain into the right internal iliac vein, so obstruction would not cause a right-sided varicocele.

C) INCORRECT:

The inferior rectal veins, part of the systemic circulation, drain the rectum below the dentate line and connect with the portal system via anastomosis with the superior rectal veins. Due to this anastomosis, portal hypertension can lead to anorectal varices. Obstruction of the right inferior rectal vein would not cause a right-sided varicocele because the right testicular vein does not drain into the right inferior rectal vein.

D) INCORRECT:

While the left testicular vein empties into the left renal vein, the right testicular vein does not empty into the right renal vein. Obstruction of the left renal vein (e.g., nutcracker syndrome, thrombosis) can result in a left-sided varicocele, but this patient's right-sided scrotal enlargement cannot be explained by right renal vein obstruction.

E) CORRECT:

Unilateral right-sided varicoceles arise due to obstruction of right pampiniform venous plexus drainage via the testicular vein into the inferior vena cava (IVC). Varicoceles are more commonly left-sided, because the left testicular vein drains into the relatively high-pressure left renal vein at a 90-degree angle, while the right testicular vein drains into the low-pressure IVC. Unilateral right-sided varicoceles should raise suspicion for a mass in the retroperitoneal space (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, lymphoma, Ormond disease) blocking the venous blood return. This patient's history of weight loss, fatigue, smoking history, and right flank tenderness is concerning for an underlying right-sided renal cell carcinoma obstructing the right testicular vein and causing the varicocele.
Image Description:

Branches of the abdominal aorta:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)

Tributaries of the inferior vena cava:
- Main confluencing tributaries: right and left common iliac veins and the median sacral vein
- Lateral tributaries: bilateral renal veins, right gonadal vein (the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein), right suprarenal vein (the left suprarenal vein drains into the left renal vein), lumbar veins, and inferior phrenic veins
- Anterior tributaries: hepatic veins

Note: As the left renal vein passes in front of the aorta, underneath the superior mesenteric artery, it is susceptible to compression between these structures, known as nutcracker phenomenon.
questions.hint: Presentation with right scrotal swelling and heaviness, exacerbated by Valsalva maneuver and alleviated by recumbency, in combination with palpable strands (i.e., “bag of worms”) and a negative transillumination test on examination suggests a right-sided varicocele.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the office because of painless enlargement of his left scrotum for the past 2 weeks. The patient reports that the enlargement is worse in the evenings, especially after playing soccer. He has not had any trauma to the testes. He has not had inguinal pain. He started to become sexually active with his girlfriend 3 weeks ago; they use condoms regularly. Examination of the external genitalia shows no groin protrusion and no penile discharge or lesions. Inguinal lymph nodes are normal. There is a palpable soft, irregular swelling above the left testis. This swelling is more prominent while standing and disappears in the supine position. Right scrotal examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The risk of bowel strangulation is increased in patients with inguinal and scrotal hernias, which can manifest as a painless scrotal swelling that increases in size on standing up and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. However, such hernias typically manifest with pain localized to the inguinal region and a visible or palpable groin bulge. An isolated soft scrotal mass is not characteristic of a groin hernia.

B) INCORRECT:

A scrotal hematoma can occur following the rupture of a varicocele, but this complication is extremely rare and only a few cases have been reported to date.

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for testicular torsion include puberty (due to the sudden increase in testicular volume), testicular tumors, testicles with a horizontal lie, undescended testes, a spermatic cord with a long intrascrotal portion, and extension of the tunica vaginalis over the proximal spermatic cord (bell-clapper anatomical variant). However, this patient has a varicocele, which does not increase the risk of testicular torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptorchidism, which manifests as an empty scrotal sac, is a known risk factor for a testicular tumor. A palpable lump may be present in the inguinal region if the undescended testis is located within the inguinal canal. In this patient, however, both the testes are palpated within the scrotal sac. Intermittent hemiscrotal swelling with cord-like structures above the testis indicates a varicocele, which is not a known risk factor for testicular tumors.

E) CORRECT:

Varicoceles can result in testicular atrophy and infertility. The most probable mechanism is impaired spermatogenesis as a result of increased testicular temperature and testicular ischemia (due to increased intratesticular pressure, venous stasis, and/or vasoconstriction secondary to catecholamine reflux from the adrenal gland). The diagnosis of a varicocele is confirmed by ultrasonography, which should reveal dilated pampiniform veins.

In young men, semen analysis should be performed regularly to assess sperm number and quality. Most asymptomatic patients do not require intervention. Definitive treatment with laparoscopic varicocelectomy or percutaneous embolization is indicated for those with intractable discomfort and/or abnormalities on semen analysis.
Image Description:

A varicocele is a dilatation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum.
questions.hint: Vague discomfort and soft, irregular swelling in the scrotal region that enlarges on standing or with a Valsalva maneuver suggests a varicocele, which most commonly occurs during adolescence.

questions.text:
An 8-day-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to a right-sided scrotal swelling present since birth. The swelling becomes more noticeable when he cries. He has no feeding difficulties or fever and appears comfortable. On examination, the right scrotum is larger than the left. The mass is soft, non-tender, and distinct from the testis. Transillumination of the swelling produces a bright glow.
Which of the following diagnoses best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicoceles are dilated venous structures that feel like a 'bag-of-worms' and do not transilluminate, as blood does not allow light to pass through. They are more common on the left side and rare in neonates, typically presenting later in life.

B) INCORRECT:

An indirect inguinal hernia involves herniated bowel or omentum, which does not transilluminate. The mass in this case is soft, non-tender, and transilluminates, indicating fluid rather than solid or mixed tissue components.

C) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion presents with acute pain and tenderness due to spermatic cord twisting, leading to ischemia. The testis is high riding and does not transilluminate. The absence of pain and the presence of transillumination in this case suggest a fluid-filled structure, not torsion.

D) CORRECT:

A hydrocele is an accumulation of serous fluid within the tunica vaginalis surrounding the testis, often due to a patent processus vaginalis in neonates. This condition allows peritoneal fluid to enter the scrotal sac, causing a soft, non-tender mass that transilluminates with a bright glow. The swelling may become more noticeable with increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as when crying. These characteristics are consistent with a hydrocele, which often resolves spontaneously over time.

Key learning point: A scrotal mass in a newborn that transilluminates is most likely a hydrocele, which is a fluid collection in the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine visit. He was born at full term without complications. The mother reports she has never noticed the left testis in the scrotum. The child's growth and development are within normal limits. On examination, the left testis is nonpalpable in the scrotal sac, while the right testis is normally located (see report).
Ultrasound: Left testis at the superficial inguinal ring
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer a trial of human chorionic gonadotropin therapy
Delay intervention until puberty for possible spontaneous descent
Observe until 2 years of age and reassess the testis position
Refer for surgical orchidopexy within the next few months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) therapy aims to stimulate testicular descent by increasing testosterone production. However, its success rate is modest, and it carries risks such as testicular apoptosis and virilization. Surgical intervention is more effective and is recommended for an 8-month-old with the testis at the superficial inguinal ring.

B) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous testicular descent rarely occurs after 6 months of age. Delaying intervention until puberty increases risks of testicular degeneration, impaired spermatogenesis, and malignancy. Early surgical correction is recommended to optimize fertility potential and reduce associated risks.

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous descent of undescended testes is unlikely after 6 months of age. The testis is already localized at the superficial inguinal ring in this 8-month-old, indicating that further waiting is not beneficial.
