questions.text: You are seeing a 7-month-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has been healthy. His length and weight are at the 60th percentile. On examination, he has normal scrotal rugae and a circumcised penis. There is a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. The scrotum is nontender and not enlarged. A palpable mass is noted in the left inguinal canal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exploration under anesthesia is recommended in infants with cryptorchidism and nonpalpable testes in order to evaluate for the presence and location of the testes. A nonpalpable testis may be absent (blind-ending cord structures indicate absent testes), atrophic, or located anywhere along the line of testicular descent (intra-abdominal or within the inguinal canal). Since the left testicle of this infant is palpable in the left inguinal canal, exploration under anesthesia is not necessary.

B) CORRECT:

Immediate surgical treatment of undescended testes is recommended starting from the corrected age of 6 months because spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after this time. Early surgery promotes normal testicular growth and improves the chances of fertility. Because the infant has a palpable testis in the inguinal canal, orchiopexy is the surgical procedure of choice. Orchiopexy should ideally be performed between 6–12 months, but no later than 24 months of corrected age.

The rate of cryptorchidism is higher in preterm infants, such as this patient, and in patients who are small for gestational age or have low birth weight. Complications of cryptorchidism include subfertility and testicular cancer (even in patients who underwent timely intervention), inguinal hernia (due to concurrent patent processus vaginalis), and testicular torsion.

Key learning point: Orchiopexy is recommended for undescended testes that have not descended by 6 months of age to reduce risks of infertility and malignancy.
Image Description:

Failure of one or both testicles to descend to their natural position in the scrotum. Most common variations (from top to bottom):

– abdominal testis (blue): the testicle is located proximal to the internal inguinal ring
– inguinal testis (green): the testicle is located inside the inguinal canal between the external and internal inguinal ring, preventing adequate mobilization (90% of cases)
– suprascrotal testis (purple): the testicle is located distal to the internal inguinal ring and above the scrotum

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous descent of a cryptorchid testis rarely occurs after 6 months of age. Re-evaluating this patient at 3 years of age would increase the risk of complications (e.g., infertility, testicular torsion). Therefore, another step in management is required.

D) INCORRECT:

Orchiectomy for cryptorchidism may be indicated if the undescended testicle is hypoplastic, atrophic, or nonviable. Orchiectomy may also be indicated for an abdominal testis (especially in post-pubertal boys) to minimize the risk of testicular cancer or if the testicular vessels and vas deferens are too short to perform a scrotal orchiopexy, provided that the child has a normal contralateral testis. This patient has an inguinal cryptorchid testis and there is no reason to suspect impaired viability of the testis.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance for cryptorchidism is indicated in boys < 4 months of age since the majority of testicles descend spontaneously by 4 months of age. Spontaneous descent most likely occurs at this time because of a gonadotropic hormone surge (FSH and LH) at around 60–90 days of life. However, spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after 6 months of age and, therefore, reassurance is not appropriate because uncorrected cryptorchidism is associated with subfertility, infertility, testicular torsion, inguinal hernia, and testicular malignancy.
questions.hint: Spontaneous testicular descent should occur by 6 months of age.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents with a 4-week history of a painless left scrotal mass. Physical examination reveals a firm intratesticular mass that does not transilluminate. Scrotal ultrasound demonstrates a solid hypoechoic mass within the left testis with inhomogeneous echogenicity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – A solid intratesticular mass on ultrasound is highly suspicious for testicular cancer and requires urgent urology referral for radical inguinal orchiectomy.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are indicated for infectious causes like epididymitis, which typically manifests with gradual onset of pain and fever. A painless solid intratesticular mass on ultrasound is highly suspicious for malignancy, not infection.

C) INCORRECT:

CT abdomen and pelvis is part of staging workup but is obtained after orchiectomy and histopathological confirmation of testicular cancer. Staging diagnostics are not performed before establishing the diagnosis through orchiectomy.

D) INCORRECT:

STI testing would be indicated if epididymitis were suspected, particularly in sexually active young men. However, the ultrasound findings of a solid intratesticular mass make testicular cancer the primary concern rather than a sexually transmitted infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Manual detorsion is indicated for testicular torsion, which presents with acute onset of severe scrotal pain and absent testicular blood flow on ultrasound. This patient has a 4-week history of painless swelling with a solid mass on ultrasound, which is not consistent with torsion.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother for evaluation of right-sided scrotal swelling. The mother first noticed the swelling a few months ago and reports that it becomes larger toward the end of the day and is smaller in the morning. The infant is otherwise healthy, feeding well, and has no fever or irritability. On examination, there is a nontender, fluctuant swelling of the right hemiscrotum. The testis is palpable and feels normal. The swelling transilluminates brightly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An indirect inguinal hernia also results from a patent processus vaginalis and can present with scrotal swelling that changes in size. However, a hernia contains abdominal contents, such as bowel, which would feel firmer and would not transilluminate. An incarcerated hernia would be tender and irreducible, and the infant would be irritable; these findings are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion is a urologic emergency that would present acutely with severe pain, irritability, and possibly vomiting. The examination would show an exquisitely tender, high-riding testis and an absent cremasteric reflex. The chronic, nontender nature of this infant's swelling is inconsistent with torsion.

C) INCORRECT:

A varicocele is a dilation of the pampiniform plexus, often described as a bag of worms. It is extremely rare in infants and typically presents during or after puberty. Furthermore, a varicocele does not transilluminate. This patient's age makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis is an inflammation of the epididymis that would present with acute onset of pain, scrotal erythema, and tenderness, often accompanied by fever and irritability. This infant's presentation as a well-appearing, afebrile child with a chronic, nontender swelling is inconsistent with an infectious process like epididymitis.

E) CORRECT:

This infant's presentation is classic for a communicating hydrocele, which results from a patent processus vaginalis allowing peritoneal fluid to accumulate in the tunica vaginalis. The history of the swelling changing in size, becoming larger at the end of the day (due to gravity) and smaller in the morning (after lying supine), is a key feature. On examination, the nontender, fluctuant mass that transilluminates is pathognomonic for a fluid collection. Most communicating hydroceles in infants are managed with observation, as they typically resolve spontaneously by 12 months of age. Surgical intervention is considered if they persist beyond this age, become very large, or are associated with an inguinal hernia.
questions.hint: The variation in the size of the scrotal swelling throughout the day suggests a patent processus vaginalis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents with a several-month history of a dull, aching pain in his left scrotum. He reports the discomfort is worse at the end of the day, especially after standing for long periods, and is relieved by lying down. Physical examination shows a soft, nontender mass of tortuous vessels superior to the left testis. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in mass size with Valsalva maneuver
Firm, fixed nodule on the testis
Absence of the ipsilateral cremasteric reflex

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for a varicocele, which is a dilation of the pampiniform plexus veins. The Valsalva maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, which impedes venous return through the testicular vein, causing the dilated veins to further engorge and the mass to increase in size. This finding is a key diagnostic feature on physical examination. Varicoceles are more common on the left side because the left testicular vein has perpendicular drainage into the left renal vein. Although often asymptomatic, they can cause a dull ache, testicular atrophy, and are a common correctable cause of male infertility due to increased scrotal temperature.

B) INCORRECT:

A firm, fixed, or hard nodule palpated on the testis itself is highly suspicious for testicular cancer. This patient's examination shows a soft mass of tortuous vessels located superior to the testis, which is a distinct finding.

C) INCORRECT:

Loss of the cremasteric reflex is a highly sensitive sign for testicular torsion, a urologic emergency. Testicular torsion presents with acute, severe scrotal pain, not a several-month history of a dull ache that varies with position.

D) INCORRECT:

A positive Prehn sign, which is the relief of pain upon elevation of the scrotum, is a classic finding in acute epididymitis. This patient's chronic, dull, aching pain that is relieved by lying down is not consistent with the acute, inflammatory pain of epididymitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Transillumination, which involves shining a light through the scrotum, is used to identify fluid-filled structures such as a hydrocele, which will glow. A varicocele is a collection of blood-filled vessels and is therefore opaque to light, meaning it will not transilluminate.
questions.hint: The patient's description of a soft mass of tortuous vessels that worsens with prolonged standing suggests a diagnosis involving dilation of the pampiniform plexus.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man presents with a dull, aching discomfort in his left scrotum that worsens throughout the day. He denies fever or urinary problems and has no history of trauma or sexually transmitted infections. Examination reveals a soft, irregular mass along the spermatic cord that becomes more prominent when standing and diminishes when lying down. Mild tenderness is noted during palpation, and transillumination is negative.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spermatoceles present as painless, smooth, cystic lesions near the epididymis that transilluminate. The irregular, soft mass along the spermatic cord with negative transillumination and positional changes is not characteristic of a spermatocele.

B) CORRECT:

Varicocele manifests with dilation of the pampiniform plexus due to incompetent venous valves, leading to retrograde blood flow. The left-sided predominance is due to the left testicular vein draining into the left renal vein, predisposing it to increased hydrostatic pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Epididymitis typically presents with scrotal pain, fever, dysuria, or signs of infection, which are absent here. The mass's positional changes and negative transillumination suggest a vascular issue rather than inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydroceles typically present as a smooth, cystic mass with positive transillumination due to fluid collection around the testicle. The irregular mass with negative transillumination and mild tenderness is inconsistent with a hydrocele.
